awd_titl_txt: Tropospheric Photochemistry of Carbonyls: Elucidation of Quantum Yields to Quantify the Role of Ketones in Production of HOx and PAN-type Compounds in the Atmosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will use state-of-the-art measurement methods to investigate photolysis reactions that are important in the atmosphere. Specifically, the team will develop a new methodology for quantum yield measurements of complex molecules using chemical ionization mass spectrometry (CIMS). Initial efforts will focus on investigating reactions which arise from radiation interacting with ketones in the upper troposphere. The research team will use the results to better understand the concentrations of reaction species in the upper troposphere. The project will also support training of a graduate study and a postdoctoral researcher.

The researchers will use CIMS to detect radical reaction products from the photolysis of acetone and other ketones as a function of wavelength, O2, pressure, and temperature. Data will provide experimental constraints which will contribute to our understanding of the upper tropospheric HOx and PAN budgets. Additionally, this new method for measuring quantum yields has the potentially to be used in numerous future experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Measurements of organic radicals produced during organic trace gas photolysis (a process that occurs in the atmosphere due to sunlight) are critical to our understanding of the cleansing of chemicals from the troposphere, the lower part of Earth's atmosphere. This project showed the utility of chemical ionization mass spectrometry, a very selective and sensitive experimental technique, for measuring radical quantum yields in the photolysis of organic trace gases by studying acetone photolysis. Organic chemicals of interest in the atmosphere are emitted from various sources or made in the atmosphere by complex chemical reactions.

Chemical ionization mass spectrometry is well-suited to fast, speciated measurements of radicals and is thus helpful for measurements of complex photolysis mechanisms, like that of acetone in the troposphere. Acetone is a ubiquitous chemical that can be emitted or made in the lower atmosphere. 

We provide quantum yields, the number of molecules formed by light absorption, for CH3C(O) from acetone photolysis as wavelength, pressure, and temperature change to mimic the atmosphere. We also reanalyzed previous data to develop a comprehensive recommendation for atmospheric modeling.

The results of this comprehensive study are summarized in five peer-reviewed publications. One paper is already published. Two papers have been reviewed by journals, and we are submitting revised versions. Two papers await PhD defense of one student later in December of 2024.

The project trained two PhD students and one post-PhD scientist to carry out laboratory studies of atmospheric photochemistry.

 


Last Modified: 12/03/2024
Modified by: Akkihebbal R Ravishankara

Images (1 of )
  • Quantum yields for CH3C(O) as a function of wavelength and temperature, separated by pressure. The markers represent an average of at least 3 measurements at each condition, with error bars being the 1σ standard deviations.
    Tyson Berg
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Akkihebbal R Ravishankara
    Acetone quantum yields at various T
  • Schematic of the I-CIMS acetone photolysis measurement system. This is a simplified version of the schematic included in Chapter 2, with the added depiction of the reactor jacket used for cooling and heating of the photolyte mixture.
    Ravishankara
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Akkihebbal R Ravishankara
    USe of CIMS to measure QYs
  • Production of CH3C(O)O2 as a function of O2 mixing ratio, relative to production in ultra-zero air, at 280 (black circles), 290 (dark-red squares), 300 (red triangles), 308 (orange diamonds), and 320 nm (yellow diamonds). Error bars represent 1σ signal uncertainties.
    Ravishankara
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Akkihebbal R Ravishankara
    Role of O2 in acetone photolysis
  • Acetone (left axis) and the integral for jacetone normalized by the total integral (actinic calculated for SZA = 90 degrees and mid-latitude from the Tropospheric Ultraviolet and Visible Radiation (TUV) model and acetone determined from a sigmoid fit to other studies) versus wavelength
    Michael Link
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Akkihebbal R Ravishankara
    Reanalysis of previous data
  • QY for (CH3CO) at wavelengths and pressures utilized at 298 K. Data points are an average of at least five replicates. Error bars are 1 sigma; precision. The inset graphic shows (CH3CO) quantum yields from 310 to 330 nm, where we observe
    Ravishankara
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Akkihebbal R Ravishankara
    QY at 298 K
